title: Libyan Synagogue, Jaffa
text:
The Libyan synagogue of Jaffa ( "Beit haknesset lè'olei Loub") is an <a href="Mizrahi%20Jews">Mizrahi Jewish</a> synagogue built inside a former hotel in 1948 by <a href="History%20of%20the%20Jews%20in%20Libya">Jewish immigrants from Libya</a>. Located on "Rehov" "Mazal Daggim", the <a href="Pisces%20%28astrology%29">Pisces</a> (Fish) Street, in the <a href="Old%20Jaffa">historical part</a> of <a href="Jaffa">Jaffa</a>, it is the oldest synagogue in <a href="Tel%20Aviv">Tel Aviv</a>-Yafo.
History.
18th–19th century hostel.
The building was originally built as a <a href="Khan%20%28inn%29">khan</a> (a roadside <a href="hostel">hostel</a>) in 1740 near the <a href="Port%20of%20Jaffa">Port of Jaffa</a> by <a href="Ottoman%20Palestine">Ottoman authorities</a> in <a href="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>. It was the only Jewish khan in the city, available for Jewish <a href="pilgrim">pilgrim</a>s going to <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> and other holy cities in the area. In addition to reception rooms for pilgrims, the khan also had a synagogue and a "<a href="mikvah">mikvah</a>" (Jewish ritual bath). The building was also known by the name "Zonana House", named after <a href="Rabbi">Rabbi</a> Yaakov ben David Zonana, who owned it.
Rabbi <a href="Chaim%20Joseph%20David%20Azoulay">Chaim Joseph David Azoulay</a> stayed at the khan in 1757 and described the place in his memoirs as a place of "silence and tranquility". This tranquility is all relative, as sever years later another pilgrim, Rabbi Simcha Mazalevitz, wrote that the <a href="Arabs">Arabs</a> confiscated the building for the first time. At first, the Arabs allowed Jewish pilgrims, whose number had diminished, to come to the site three days a year, and later made the site completely forbidden to Jews.
Over the years the building was used for a variety of different purposes, eventually becoming a soap factory, though the Arab population continued to refer to the building as the "Jewish House."
Re-establishment as a synagogue.
The site became property of Jews after the <a href="1947%E2%80%931949%20Palestine%20war">1947–1949 Palestine war</a>. At the end of 1948, the synagogue became a cultural center for Jewish immigrants, primarily from Libya, who had settled in the neighborhood. According to legend, the Libyan Jewish community was looking for a building to serve as a synagogue, when they ran into a <a href="Franciscans">Franciscan</a> priest from <a href="St.%20Peter%27s%20Church%2C%20Jaffa">St. Peter's Church in Jaffa</a>, who gave them the keys to the building and told them that the building used to be a synagogue.
It wasn't until the 1980s that historians made the connection between the synagogue and the former Ottoman khan, due to the lack of direct proof. The researchers had always assumed that the khan had been destroyed between the end of 18th century and the beginning of the 19th century during the <a href="Arab%20Revolt%20%28disambiguation%29">Arab revolts</a>.
The Libyan Jews began to leave the <a href="Old%20City%20of%20Jaffa">Old City of Jaffa</a>, moving to more modern neighborhoods. The Old City eventually was emptied of most of its residents and became a artistic and tourist destination. Despite the changes to the neighborhood, the synagogue continued to conduct <a href="shabbat">shabbat</a> and holiday services, but found it difficult to form a <a href="minyan">minyan</a>, to the point that congregants, often older people, would appeal to tourists to form a minyan. Today the Old City location is not used for Shabbat services and the congregation has a new location in <a href="Neighborhoods%20of%20Tel%20Aviv">Yafo D</a>. However, descendents of Libyan immigrants, even those living outside the city, continue to come to the site to celebrate their <a href="Bar%20Mitzvah">Bar Mitzvah</a> or their <a href="Jewish%20wedding">wedding</a>.
Ilana Goor Museum.
In 1995, the east wing of the building was transformed into the <a href="Ilana%20Goor%20Museum">Ilana Goor Museum</a>.
Description.
The synagogue is found within the tourist areas of the Old City of Jaffa, along ancient <a href="Sett%20%28paving%29">limestone paved</a> streets. Nothing distinguishes the exterior of the synagogue from other buildings except the <a href="Star%20of%20David">Star of David</a> above the <a href="lintel">lintel</a> of the door and an engraved stone on the wall to the left of the door indicating in Hebrew and English the origins of the building: 
One enters the synagogue through a wooden door. The sanctuary is small, with low <a href="vaulted%20ceiling">vaulted ceiling</a>s. The sanctuary is divided into three parts with the <a href="Torah%20ark">Ark</a> carved into the wall in the center of the room. The <a href="Bimah%20%28platform%29">bimah</a> is situated perpendicular to the Ark and occupies a large part of the center of the room. The back of the room is the only place with a window and has a table and chairs to facilitate study. The walls are painted white.
